importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the hearing where U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis questioned federal officials about the response to Chicago protests during Operation Midway Blitz.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Operation Midway Blitz operated in Chicagoland, resulting in over 1,000 arrests of migrants across Illinois, forming the context for the protests and judicial inquiry.

keyTakeAways: Judge Sara Ellis expanded her temporary restraining order to require federal agents on the ground during protests to turn on body-worn cameras when encountering demonstrators, citing concerns that agents used force—like tear gas and pepper balls—without warning.
CBP agents in Chicago (over 200) are required to wear body cameras, and are aware of the requirement, according to Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick.
ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued body cameras; they were only issued to one or two field offices and would require congressional approval for further distribution.
ICE agents are trained in crowd control, use of force, and how to handle journalists, including directing press inquiries and allowing media observation as long as they do not interfere.

A pastor, Rev. David Black, reported being hit with pepper balls multiple times during a protest outside the Broadview detention facility, claiming no prior warning and stating that others shielded him from the force.
ICE leadership has been described as a 'revolving door,' with frequent changes in top officials such as Russell Hott, who left the Chicago area to return to Washington, DC.

The Trump administration has denied media reports of tear gas use without warning during a demonstration in Albany Park, though ICE leadership acknowledges reports are reviewed by internal oversight bodies for policy compliance.
Judge Ellis plans to depose Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino, chief patrol agent at CBP, to obtain firsthand accounts of events on the ground during the protests.

namedEntities.name: Operation Midway Blitz

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis is conducting a judicial review of federal enforcement actions during Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE operation in Chicago that led to over 1,000 arrests of migrants between September and October 2025. In response to escalating protests and concerns about the use of force—including tear gas and pepper balls—Ellis expanded her temporary restraining order to require federal agents to activate body-worn cameras during demonstrations. While CBP agents are mandated to use cameras, ICE Special Response Teams lack them and have not been issued new devices. Agents are trained in crowd control and media interactions, but a pastor reported being struck multiple times with pepper balls without warning. The federal leadership has been described as unstable, with frequent changes in top officials like Russell Hott, who left Chicago to return to Washington. Judge Ellis plans to depose Hott and Gregory Bovino to obtain firsthand accounts of events on the ground, while the White House has denied reports of unapproved force use. This hearing underscores tensions between federal enforcement authority and public accountability, especially in the context of protest responses and media transparency.
title: Judge presses federal officials on response to Chicago protests
